pros: I find the job fulfilling, and it really gives me the feeling like I'm doing my part to help people in the city navigate our ridiculous healthcare system. I love being able to work with the people for the people.
cons: High turnover rate, and as more people leave for private clinics that pay better and have better benefits, new hires are seeming less and less competent because management seems desperate. Management is also very "my way is the only way," and doesn't always listen to suggestions from admin who know what needs to improve within their own department.

review_title: Happy Employees make Happy Clients, just a thought...
pros: Salary, benefits, and co-workers are great. Always new things added to help the patients and sometimes us as well. Everyone looks out for one another which is helpful.
cons: The Constant addition of rules that are being made up in order to “ keep us in our place” is ridiculous. The favouritism is appalling. Managers constantly bulling staff for example ; “ I could fire all of you. I could replace all of you so easily.” Basically  threatening our jobs on a regular basis. There are cameras installed illegally in terms of them watching our every movement and Cameras are not illegal themselves but are supposed to be angle at dead zone in the office not directly on staff . Having to be available 8 hours After a shift is over for a new shift when on call which is also illegal when it’s supposed to be 12 hours between shifts to take into account 2 hours of travel on both sides. There’s more but what’s the point.

pros: The people theirs around the hospital know how to treat you like family. I felt like I was part of some big family outside my department. Except HR and Pharmacy everything else was amazing.
cons: The co-workers (Technicians and some Pharmacist) were amazing people to work with, the supervising staff were more of a bully type of people. Their job was to make peoples life really miserable. It got so bad that I end up having a burn out. I couldn't take their abusive attitude towards me anymore that I cracked and left without saying a proper good bye. I do miss the technicians and some other employees....

pros: People are overall very well meaning, and easy to get along with for the most part. I actually enjoy walking thru the doors to start my shift. Employees, employees, employees, they're a fantastic bunch of people. Restaurants all around on cote st catherine. The volunteers are beyond awesome. Working conditions, compared to similarly sized institutions, are above average from my perspective. Gorgeous new K pavillion, indoor parking. Piano on 6th floor. Music shows in summer onsite.
cons: Due to budget constraints, work load seems to slowly but surely increase year by year. And as responsibilities merge, its not reflected in the pay. Cafeteria closed.  3 Second Cup's.

review_title: They take care of patients, but not their employees
pros:
- They provide high-quality care despite all.
- Staff are so very friendly and easy to get along with anywhere you got. Everybody is trying to help everybody. it is really heartwarming.
- 3 Second Cups in the hospital. 3!!
- Easy to move from department to department. The culture is different on every unit, so if you don't like one, there's always other options
- No strict hierarchy as in many other hospitals. Everybody is a valued professional.
- Can get by even if your French isn't great as long as you're putting an effort into learning.
cons:
BUDGET CUTS ARE A KILLER
- Expect working hard and often skipping your breaks or leaving late.
- Hospital is increasingly busy but no new funds or resources are allocated for staff to help deal with the changes. As a result, nurses, lab techs, doctors, and pharmacists are working extra hard to maintain the quality of care and patient satisfaction at the cost of their own sanity. We're all en route to burnout.
- Closed budget friendly cafeteria that was popular among employees in favour of overpriced private restaurants. No more affordable healthy meal options available.
- Seniority rules all. Can't get a leave of absence without 5 years of seniority. Vacation and work schedule are scheduled by seniority. For a full-time position, one must usually work at least 5 years, on some units or clinics, 10 years.
- extra conservative staffing on weekends - because patients are less sick on weekends?!?
- The hospital invests in the infection prevention and control department more and more and yet bed coordinators and managers do not follow any infection control rules and protocols. Their priority is to unload the ER department and they will book any bed for any patient. They will say "a bed is a bed". And that is how outbreaks begin.
- Patients often come with high expectations of care and are frequently disappointed at how little attention they're paid or how slow their treatments progress. With good reason. But the ones who get most of that rage are nurses despite working so very hard.

review_title: Great  place for a new RN grad
pros: Its a teaching hospital with a diverse population, there is a lot of unique learning opportunities for nurses.  It's great place to finish your BSN if your college RN.
cons: It is important that to understand it is very easy to be part of rumors and gossip. especially if your knew, be very careful who you socialize with. Residents are notorious with trying to go out with new nurses.

review_title: Fulfilling, important work is done in a professional environment
pros:
Fabulous sense of unity and purpose. 
Good benefits, including 4 weeks holiday, 9 sick days and 13 statutory holidays. Access to medical care as part of being on site. 
Flexible work schedule
Fulfilling work, excellent output and ability to contribute
cons:
Far from my home 
We work on a budget in an older building, thus suffer from thermo-regulation issues, old furniture etc. 
Food services close early.

pros: supportive work environment! staff is generally very friendly. loved working there, but moved out of town.
cons: it's old building and lots of renovations were taking place when i worked there. The hospital staff was exposed to dust and particulate matter. I personally had to consult a doctor on several occasions due to breathing issues, as a result.  except for this "minor" issue, great place to work.
